title: How to build deeper, more robust relationships | Carole Robin (Stanford professor, “Touchy Feely”)
key_insights: The 15% rule: step slightly outside your comfort zone to build deeper relationships without reaching the danger zone
Anger is a secondary emotion - underneath it is usually fear or hurt, which are connecting emotions rather than distancing ones
Stay on your side of the net when giving feedback - focus on observable behaviors and your feelings, not attributions about the other person's intent
Use the formula: 'When you do X (behavior), I feel Y (emotion), and I'm telling you this because Z (desired outcome)'
Ask questions starting with what, when, where, how - avoid 'why' questions which make people defensive
Appropriate vulnerability makes leaders stronger, not weaker, by allowing others to see them as human and trustworthy
Address pinches before they become crunches - deal with small irritations before they escalate
Giving advice often hinders relationships - being a thought partner and asking questions is more effective

guest_background.current_role: Founder of Leaders in Tech nonprofit

topics_discussed: The Stanford 'Touchy Feely' course and its impact
The three realities framework for communication
Mental models that limit professional growth
The art of inquiry and asking better questions
The six characteristics of exceptional relationships
Dealing with anger as a secondary emotion
Repair strategies when conversations go wrong
The Leaders in Tech program structure
AFOG: Another F*cking Opportunity for Growth
Long COVID's impact on leadership lessons
memorable_quotes: Are you human after all? - To this day, I believe that was the day I became a leader
A willingness to be vulnerable makes you not less influential as a leader
We don't understand that we are only privy to two out of the three realities, so I know what's going on for me and I know what I did. I have no idea what happened on your end
frameworks_mentioned: Stay on Your Side of the Net
The Six Characteristics of Exceptional Relationships
recommended_for: Anyone looking to improve interpersonal skills
Leaders wanting to build stronger company cultures
summary: Carole Robin, former Stanford professor and founder of Leaders in Tech, shares decades of expertise on building exceptional relationships through vulnerability, better feedback, and interpersonal competence. This episode provides actionable frameworks for leaders to communicate more effectively, resolve conflicts, and create stronger professional relationships.
